column4: I'm having problems with the Nvidia drivers that come with ubuntu so I want to install the ones from the nvidia website, however that too is problematic since it claims that I don't seem to have the right kernel source, though I'm pretty sure I do
you need linux-headers installed
geforce4 440 go
(laptop)
well, from the logfile the installer spit out
both, but tv out doesn't work
(legacy work but not with tv-out, glx doesn't work at all)
I already did
I uninstalled both since I wanted to try the nvidia ones
you need to "sudo apt-get install linux-header-`uname -r`" to get the stuff that the nVidia kernel module builds against
erm, linux-headers- rather
I've already got the headers
in that case it ought to compile fine
rambo3:they compile, but don't want to install
I've used the nVidia package with linux-headers over pretty much every kernel Ubuntu have released since breezy :)
ERROR: Unable to load the kernel module 'nvidia.ko'.  This is most likely
because the kernel module was built using the wrong kernel source files.
can you manually specify the path to the kernel sources?
s/sources/headers/
I suppose its also possible that /usr/src/linux is symlinked to the wrong directory (it shouldn't exist at all)
I specified the path with the installer (only way it would allow me to compile the module) afterwards it tell me it can't load the module
can my gcc be the wrong version?
linux-src-`anything` doesn't exist :)
no. the clue is in the error message
